A. 1
B. 2
C. 3
D. 4

To determine how many 3×1×1 waffles can fit into a 2×2×4 box without breaking any, we must consider the constraints imposed by the box’s dimensions and the shape of the waffles.

---

### Step 1: Analyze the Box and Waffle Dimensions

- **Box dimensions**: 2 × 2 × 4 (length × width × height)
- **Waffle dimensions**: 3 × 1 × 1 (length × width × height)

The waffle is **3 units long** in one dimension and **1 unit** in the other two. The box has a **maximum length of 4**, which is the only dimension that can accommodate the 3-unit length of the waffle without exceeding any side.

---

### Step 2: Determine Maximum Number of Waffles that Fit

The only viable orientation is placing the **3-unit side of the waffle along the 4-unit side of the box**. Since:

- The waffle is 1 unit in the other two dimensions (width and height),
- The base of the box (2×2) can fit **2 waffles along each dimension**, resulting in **4 waffles** in total.

Each waffle will extend 3 units into the 4-unit dimension and occupy 1×1 in the 2×2 base. This arrangement uses the space efficiently without overlapping and respects the "no breaking" constraint.

---

### Step 3: Subtract to Determine How Many Waffles to Eat

- You have **7 waffles**.
- Only **4 waffles** can fit in the box.
- To make room for the rest, you must **eat 7 - 4 = 3 waffles**.

---

### Final Answer

$$
\boxed{C}
$$
